choices.text: MDR plus resistance to fluoroquinolone
MDR plus resistance to fluoroquinolone and streptomycin
MDR plus resistance to fluoroquinolone, linezolide and bedaquiline
MDR plus resistance to amikacin

questions.text: Pre-XDR TB is defined as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MDR plus resistance to fluoroquinolone

 

Option A:

 

Pre-extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis (Pre-XDR TB) is defined as multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) with additional resistance to any fluoroquinolone. MDR-TB is resistant to at least both isoniazid (H) and rifampicin (R), which are the two mainstays of TB therapy. The additional resistance to fluoroquinolones in Pre-XDR TB presents a significant challenge to treatment, necessitating the use of second-line drugs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: While resistance to streptomycin may occur, it does not define Pre-XDR TB; the critical factor is resistance to fluoroquinolones.

 

Option C: The definition provided in this option refers to extensively drug-resistant TB (XDR-TB), not Pre-XDR TB.

 

Option D: Resistance to amikacin alone, in addition to MDR-TB, does not define Pre-XDR TB without concurrent resistance to fluoroquinolones.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Antitubercular drugs causing ophthalmic toxicity is__________?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ethambutol

 

Option C:

 

Ethambutol is known for causing ophthalmic toxicity, specifically optic neuritis, which can lead to symptoms such as loss of vision, color blindness (especially red-green color blindness), and blurred vision. This side effect is dose-related and generally reversible upon discontinuation of the drug. Regular ophthalmic examinations are recommended for patients on ethambutol to monitor for early signs of visual impairment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: While it does have side effects, including peripheral neuropathy and hepatotoxicity, it does not typically cause ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Option B. Rifampicin: Known for causing reddish-orange discoloration of bodily fluids and hepatotoxicity, but not associated with direct ophthalmic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antitubercular Drugs

choices.text: Nevirapine - Nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor

questions.text: All the following anti-HIV drugs and their mechanism of action are correctly matched EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Darunavir-Fusion inhibitor

 

Option D:

 

Darunavir is incorrectly matched with the mechanism of action of a fusion inhibitor. In reality, Darunavir is a protease inhibitor.

 

Protease inhibitors work by blocking the protease enzyme, which is essential for the HIV virus to replicate and produce mature viral particles. Fusion inhibitors, on the other hand, such as Enfuvirtide, work by preventing the fusion of the HIV virus with the host cell membrane, thereby blocking the entry of the virus into the cell.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Correct because Raltegravir is an Integrase Strand Transfer Inhibitor (INSTI), which inhibits the integrase enzyme responsible for the integration of viral DNA into the host cell genome.

 

Option B. Correct because Indinavir is a Protease Inhibitor (PI), which inhibits the HIV protease enzyme necessary for the maturation of the viral particle.

 

Option C. Correct because Nevirapine is a Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitor (NNRTI), which binds directly to the reverse transcriptase enzyme and inhibits its function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-retroviral Drug

questions.text: Which of the following sites in the diagram shown below represents the mechanism of development of drug resistance in MRSA?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. D

 

Option D:

 

The diagram shows various mechanisms of antibiotic resistance:

 

A. Inactivation of drug by enzymes - This represents a common resistance mechanism where bacteria produce enzymes that chemically modify or degrade the antibiotic, rendering it ineffective.

 

B. Activation of drug efflux pumps - These are proteins that actively transport antibiotics out of the cell, reducing the intracellular concentration of the drug and thereby its efficacy.

 

C. Inhibition of drug uptake - Some bacteria can alter their cell envelope to prevent antibiotics from entering the cell.

 

D. Alteration of drug target - Bacteria can mutate or modify the target of the antibiotic so that the drug no longer binds effectively.

 

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is known for its resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics, which include methicillin and related drugs. This resistance is primarily due to the alteration of the drug target, where MRSA produces a modified penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a or PBP2') that does not bind methicillin or other beta-lactam antibiotics effectively, allowing the bacteria to continue synthesizing its cell wall even in the presence of the antibiotic.

 

In the diagram, the mechanism corresponding to the alteration of the drug target, which would represent the mechanism of drug resistance in MRSA, is D - Alteration of drug target.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect because MRSA resistance is not primarily due to enzyme inactivation.

 

Option B: Incorrect because MRSA resistance is not due to activation of efflux pumps.

 

Option C: Incorrect because MRSA resistance is not due to inhibition of drug uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: This type of killing (green) is seen with all the following drugs EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Aminoglycosides

 

Option A:

 

  • The green curve represents Time dependent killing (TDK)
  • Some antibiotics kill best when concentration persists above MIC for LONGER DURATIONS of the dosing interval.
  • The parameter that best describes Time Dependent Killing (TDK) is the time for which concentration remains above MIC (T>MIC).
  • TDK is shown by Beta lactams and vancomycin.
  • Drug following TDK like beta-lactam antibiotics need to be given as small doses, more frequently.
  • The red curve represents Concentration dependent killing. It is followed by aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones.
  • Aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin and tobramycin, exhibit concentration-dependent killing (CDK), which means their effectiveness increases with higher drug concentrations. The higher the peak concentration above the MIC, typically the better the antibacterial activity. This is in contrast to time-dependent killing antibiotics, where the duration of time the drug concentration exceeds the MIC is the critical factor for effectiveness.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Beta-lactams: Incorrect as an exception. Beta-lactams, including penicillins, cephalosporins, and carbapenems like imipenem, kill bacteria more effectively when their concentration remains above the MIC for a prolonged period, characteristic of TDK.

 

Option C. Vancomycin: Incorrect as an exception. Vancomycin also follows TDK, with its effectiveness depending on maintaining drug levels above the MIC for the majority of the dosing interval.

 

Option D. Imipenem: Incorrect as an exception. Imipenem is a beta-lactam antibiotic, and like other beta-lactams, it exhibits TDK.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aminoglycosides, which follow concentration-dependent killing, differ from beta-lactams and vancomycin, which are time-dependent killers, necessitating different approaches to dosing to achieve the best therapeutic outcomes.

questions.text:
A male patient presented with the features shown in figure. Which could be the causative agent: 

 

 

  1. Spironolactone
  2. Metronidazole
  3. Diazepam
  4. Ketoconazole
questions.solution:
Ans. D. a & d

 

Option D:

 

Spironolactone (a) is a potassium-sparing diuretic with anti-androgenic effects, which can lead to gynecomastia due to its action as an aldosterone antagonist. It interferes with the action of male sex hormones, which can cause the development of male breast tissue.

 

Ketoconazole (d) is an antifungal medication that can inhibit steroid synthesis, including testosterone, leading to an imbalance of sex hormones that may contribute to gynecomastia.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Metronidazole (b): While known for various side effects, it is not typically associated with gynecomastia.
  • Diazepam (c): A benzodiazepine used for anxiety and seizures, is also not commonly linked to the development of gynecomastia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs causing gynecomastia are: (DISC-KO)

 

  • Digitalis
  • Isoniazid
  • Spironolactone
  • Cimetidine
  • Ketoconazole
  • Oestrogens

choices.text: Enzymatic cleavage of drug
Increased efflux of drug
Altered penicillin binding site
Alteration in 50s ribosome structure

questions.text: Antibiotic resistance by beta lactamases is conferred by
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Enzymatic cleavage of drug

 

Option A:

 

  • Beta-lactamases are enzymes that are produced by bacteria and can confer resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics, such as penicillins and cephalosporins. These enzymes work by breaking the beta-lactam ring structure of the antibiotic, which is essential for its antibacterial activity. By breaking this ring, the beta-lactamases render the antibiotic ineffective and resistant to the bacteria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. increased efflux of drug, refers to a mechanism of antibiotic resistance where the bacteria pump the antibiotic out of the cell, reducing the concentration of the drug within the cell and making it less effective. It is commonly seen against tetracyclines.

 

Option C. altered penicillin binding site, refers to a mechanism of resistance where the bacteria modify the target site of the antibiotic, such as the bacterial cell wall, to prevent the antibiotic from binding effectively. This mechanism of drug resistance result in MRSA.

 

Option D. alteration in 50s ribosome structure, is a mechanism of resistance to antibiotics that target the bacterial ribosome, such as macrolides and tetracyclines. Bacteria can modify the structure of the ribosome to prevent the antibiotic from binding effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-lactamases confer antibiotic resistance through the enzymatic cleavage of the beta-lactam ring of antibiotics, rendering them ineffective against the bacteria producing these enzymes. This mechanism highlights the importance of using beta-lactamase inhibitors in combination with beta-lactam antibiotics to combat resistant strains effectively.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the dermatology clinic with a 6-month history of a persistent, itchy rash on her feet. She reports a history of athlete's foot and nail fungus in the past. On examination, there are areas of scaling, erythema, and maceration on her feet. A potassium hydroxide (KOH) test confirms the presence of dermatophytes. The dermatologist prescribes terbinafine for the treatment of the fungal infection. What is the mechanism of action of terbinafine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Squalene epoxidase inhibitor.

 

Option B:

 

Terbinafine operates by selectively inhibiting squalene epoxidase, a key enzyme in the ergosterol biosynthesis pathway for fungi. This inhibition leads to a toxic buildup of squalene within the fungal cell and a lack of ergosterol, which is crucial for maintaining the cell membrane integrity of the fungus. This dual effect disrupts cell membrane function and leads to fungal cell death.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 14 α-demethylase inhibitor: This describes the mechanism of action of azole antifungals like fluconazole, which inhibit ergosterol synthesis at a different stage than terbinafine.

 

Option C. Inhibition of synthesis of β-1,3-glucan: Drugs like caspofungin work by this mechanism, which targets the fungal cell wall rather than the cell membrane.

 

Option D. Thymidylate synthase inhibitor: This describes the action of antifungal agents such as flucytosine, which interfere with DNA and RNA synthesis in fungal cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terbinafine's unique mechanism of inhibiting squalene epoxidase makes it highly effective for treating dermatophyte infections, such as athlete's foot and onychomycosis, by targeting a critical component of the fungal cell membrane synthesis pathway.

questions.text: A patient is on indinavir, zidovudine, lamivudine, and ketoconazole. He developed breast hypertrophy, nephrolithiasis, hyperlipidemia, and central obesity; identify the drug causing these side effects amongst all?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Indinavir

 

Option B:

 

Indinavir, a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV, is known for causing a range of side effects due to its impact on metabolic processes and renal function:

 

  • Nephrolithiasis: Indinavir can lead to the formation of kidney stones (crystals), causing pain and potential complications related to kidney function.
  • Hyperlipidemia: This drug class, including indinavir, is associated with increases in cholesterol and triglyceride levels, contributing to cardiovascular risk.
  • Central Obesity: Protease inhibitors have been linked to changes in fat distribution, leading to increased abdominal fat which is part of the lipodystrophy syndrome seen in some HIV patients.

 

Breast Hypertrophy Connection:

  • While breast hypertrophy in this context is more likely associated with ketoconazole, which can cause gynecomastia by altering hormone levels, the other symptoms align more closely with the known side effects of indinavir.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lamivudine: This nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) is not typically associated with metabolic effects like hyperlipidemia, nephrolithiasis, or central obesity.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole: An antifungal medication that can cause hormonal changes leading to gynecomastia but is less likely to cause the other side effects noted.

 

Option D. Zidovudine: Another NRTI, known for potential bone marrow suppression and anemia, but not typically linked to the metabolic or renal side effects mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indinavir is recognized for its potential to cause both metabolic disturbances and nephrolithiasis, which necessitates careful monitoring of patients on this medication for these side effects. Patients need to be aware of these risks and manage them proactively with their healthcare provider.

questions.text: Most effective bactericidal drug against mycobacterium leprae is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ofloxacin

 

Option B:

 

Ofloxacin stands out as a highly effective bactericidal agent against Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium responsible for leprosy. This drug, part of the fluoroquinolone class, works by inhibiting key bacterial enzymes—DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV—which are vital for DNA replication and transcription in bacteria. The interruption of these processes leads to the inability of the bacteria to multiply and results in their death, making ofloxacin a potent option for treating leprosy. It is important to note that while rifampicin is generally considered the most effective, ofloxacin is also highly recommended due to its efficacy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythromycin: This antibiotic is not effective against Mycobacterium leprae and is not used in the treatment of leprosy. It primarily targets gram-positive bacteria and some gram-negative bacteria, but does not cover mycobacteria.

 

Option C. Cotrimoxazole: Similar to erythromycin, cotrimoxazole is ineffective against Mycobacterium leprae. While it can be used against a variety of bacterial infections, leprosy is not one of them.

 

Option D. Amoxicillin: This drug, also ineffective against Mycobacterium leprae, is used for a broad spectrum of bacterial infections but lacks the necessary activity to combat mycobacteria like those causing leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ofloxacin is a crucial drug in the treatment of leprosy due to its bactericidal action against Mycobacterium leprae, primarily through the inhibition of DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, essential enzymes for bacterial survival and replication.

questions.text: Which of the following antifungal agents is used topically?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Nystatin

 

Option D:

 

Nystatin is a polyene antifungal that is commonly used topically to treat fungal infections of the skin, mucous membranes, and intestinal tract. Its mechanism involves binding to ergosterol, a critical component of the fungal cell membrane. By binding to ergosterol, Nystatin disrupts the membrane integrity, causing leakage of cell components and ultimately leading to fungal cell death. This mode of action is effective against a variety of yeasts and molds, making Nystatin a versatile option for topical fungal infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Griseofulvin: This antifungal is typically administered orally and is used to treat scalp, skin, and nail infections caused by dermatophytes. It is not commonly used topically.

 

Option B. Itraconazole: An azole antifungal that is primarily used orally or intravenously to treat systemic fungal infections. It is not suitable for topical use.

 

Option C. Voriconazole: Another azole antifungal that is used orally or intravenously, especially for severe fungal infections such as invasive aspergillosis. It is not formulated for topical use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topically Antifungals

choices.text: Azoles: Inhibit lanosterol alpha demethylase thereby preventing ergosterol synthesis.
Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis thus prevents mitosis.
Echinocandins: Act by inhibiting beta 1,3 glucan synthesis.
Amphotericin B:  Binds with ergosterol resulting in disrupting of cell membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrongly matched regarding the mechanism of action of antifungal drugs?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis thus prevents mitosis.

 

Option B:

 

The correct mechanism of action for Flucytosine (5-FC) is not the inhibition of microtubule synthesis, but rather the inhibition of DNA synthesis. Flucytosine is converted into 5-fluorouracil within fungal cells, where it inhibits DNA synthesis by disrupting the action of DNA polymerases and incorporation into RNA, thus interfering with fungal RNA and protein synthesis. The statement that Flucytosine inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus prevents mitosis is incorrect and likely confuses Flucytosine with Griseofulvin, which does inhibit microtubule function.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Azoles: Correctly matched. Azoles work by inhibiting lanosterol 14α-demethylase, an enzyme involved in ergosterol synthesis, which is a critical component of the fungal cell membrane.

 

Option C. Echinocandins: Correctly matched. Echinocandins, including drugs such as Caspofungin, Micafungin, and Anidulafungin, inhibit the synthesis of β-(1,3)-glucan, an essential component of the fungal cell wall.

 

Option D. Amphotericin B: Correctly matched. Amphotericin B binds to ergosterol in fungal cell membranes, creating pores that increase membrane permeability leading to the leakage of essential intracellular components.

 

Educational Objective:
